clinical_study.brief_title: Meaning Centered Psychotherapy for Palliative Care Patients (MCP-PC)
clinical_study.official_title: Development of Meaning Centered Psychotherapy for Palliative Care Patients

brief_summary.textblock: This randomized, controlled trial evaluates the effectiveness of an adaptation of a well-established brief, structured existential psychotherapy (Meaning Centered Psychotherapy) specifically tailored to the needs of palliative care patients (MCP-PC). Terminally ill patients with cancer who have been hospitalized in a palliative care hospital will be randomly assigned to either MCP-PC or enhanced usual care. Patients will complete a very short battery of self-report measures before the 3-session intervention, and again 2 and 4 weeks later to determine whether treatment has bolstered spiritual and psychological well-being and improved quality of life.

primary_outcome.description: Overall spiritual well-being as measured through the self-report FACIT SWB scale

secondary_outcome.description: Self-report rating scale, the Hopelessness Assessment in Illness scale
Subscale derived from the Life Attitude Profile, a self-report measure of meaning and purpose
Single item rating of overall quality of life derived from the McGill Quality of Life Questionnaire
Abbreviated version of the Schedule of Attitudes towards Hastened Death, a measure of desire for hastened death

intervention.description: Manualized, 3-session existential psychotherapy (30-45 minutes/session) with an optional 4th "booster" session. Content focuses on enhancing patients sense of meaning and purpose in life.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Terminal illness with life expectancy of less than 6 months; hospitalized at Calvary Hospital (Bronx NY), English speaking
Exclusion Criteria:
- Cognitive impairment or severe psychiatric symptoms that preclude informed consent or participation in treatment.
